gw.api.domain.invoice

Class PeriodicDateSequence

  • java.lang.Object
    • gw.api.domain.invoice.DateSequence
      • gw.api.domain.invoice.PeriodicDateSequence
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    MonthlyDateSequence, WeeklyDateSequence

    public abstract class PeriodicDateSequence
extends DateSequence
    A PeriodicDateSequence is a date sequence in which the dates occur once per period. It extends infinitely far back in time and infinitely into the future. Subclasses define the length of each period.

    The anchorDateTime is one date in the sequence, and all other dates in the sequence are a multiple of one period from that date.

    Author:
    rrubin

    • Constructor Detail

      • PeriodicDateSequence

        public PeriodicDateSequence(org.joda.time.DateTime anchorDateTime)
        Returns a date sequence with the given anchor date. The sequence will provide consecutive dates. For example a monthly sequence anchored on July 1st will contain sequence dates of August 1st, September 1st etc.
        Parameters:
        anchorDateTime - the anchoring date for the sequence

      • datesInInterval

        public java.util.SortedSet<org.joda.time.DateTime> datesInInterval(org.joda.time.Interval dateInterval)
        Description copied from class: DateSequence
        Returns all of the dates from this sequence that are within the given interval.
        Specified by:
        datesInInterval in class DateSequence
        Parameters:
        dateInterval - the interval to use (inclusive on start, exclusive on the end)
        Returns:

      • getAnchorDateTime

        protected org.joda.time.DateTime getAnchorDateTime()

      • anchorDatePlusPeriods

        protected abstract org.joda.time.DateTime anchorDatePlusPeriods(int numberOfPeriods)

      • fullPeriodsFromAnchorDateTo

        protected abstract int fullPeriodsFromAnchorDateTo(org.joda.time.DateTime dateTime)
        Returns the number of full periods from the anchor date to the given date. For example, if there are 3.5 periods from the anchor date to the given date, returns 3. If the given date is before the anchor date and there are -2.4 periods from the anchor date to the given date, returns -2.
        Parameters:
        dateTime - the given date
        Returns:
        the number of full periods from the anchor date to the given date
